sols_html:
To use the method of separation of variables, we write \(u\) as

\[\begin{aligned} u(r,\theta) = R(r ) \Theta (\theta) . \,\end{aligned}\]

We compute that

\[\begin{aligned} u_r(r,\theta) = R'(r ) \Theta(\theta), \; u_{rr}(r,\theta) = R''(r ) \Theta (\theta),\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} u_{\theta \theta}(r,\theta) = R(r ) \Theta'' (\theta) . \,\end{aligned}\]

Substitute the above into our differential equation

\[\begin{aligned} u_{rr} + \frac{1}{r} u_r + \frac{1}{r^2} u_{\theta \theta} = 0,\end{aligned}\]

we get that

\[\begin{aligned} R'' \Theta + \frac{1}{r} R' \Theta + \frac{1}{r^2} R \Theta'' = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

Next, we would like to group all the \(R\) terms onto one side and all the \(\Theta\) terms onto another, so divide the entire equation by \(R \Theta\) to get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{R'' \Theta}{R \Theta} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{R' \Theta}{R \Theta} + \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{R \Theta''}{R \Theta} = 0\end{aligned}\]

which gives

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{R''}{R} + \frac{1}{r} \frac{R'}{R} + \frac{1}{r^2} \frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

To get rid of the factor of \(\frac{1}{r^2}\) in the last term on the left, we will multiply the equation by \(r^2\) to get

\[\begin{aligned} r^2 \frac{R''}{R} + r \frac{R'}{R} + \frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} = 0\end{aligned}\]

which gives

\[\begin{aligned} r^2 \frac{R''}{R} + r \frac{R'}{R} = -\frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} .\end{aligned}\]

Here, \(r\) and \(\theta\) are independent of each other. However, the right hand side of the equation is a function of \(r\) while the right hand side a function of \(\theta\), so both sides of the equation must be equal to a constant which we will denote \(\mu\). In other words, we have

\[\begin{aligned} r^2 \frac{R''}{R} + r \frac{R'}{R} = -\frac{\Theta''}{\Theta} = \mu .\end{aligned}\]

This gives us two equations

\[\begin{aligned} r^2 R'' + r R' = \mu R \;\; \text{and} \;\; - \Theta'' = \mu \Theta .\end{aligned}\]

We will first solve the equation for \(R\). Before we go ahead to do so, we would like to figure out the boundary conditions for \(R\). The boundary conditions

\[\begin{aligned} u(1,\theta) = 0 \;\; \text{and} \;\; u(2,\theta) = 0\end{aligned}\]

imply that

\[\begin{aligned} R(1) \Theta(\theta) = 0 \;\; \text{and} \;\; R(2) \Theta(\theta) = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

Since we do not want \(\Theta\) to be \(0\) since this will give the trivial solution (i.e. \(u \equiv 0\)) which is not of interest to us. So the boundary conditions give us

\[\begin{aligned} R(1) = 0 \;\; \text{and}\;\; R(2) = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

We will now solve the equation for \(R\) which says

\[\begin{aligned} r^2 R'' + r R' - \mu R = 0 . \,\end{aligned}\]

This is the Euler’s equation and we recall that we should look for solutions in the form

\[\begin{aligned} R(r) = r^\alpha \,\end{aligned}\]

for an unknown constant \(\alpha\) to be determined. We compute that

\[\begin{aligned} R' = \alpha r^{\alpha -1} \;\; \text{and} \;\; R'' = \alpha (\alpha -1) r^{\alpha -2} .\end{aligned}\]

Substituting these into

\[\begin{aligned} r^2 R'' + r R' - \mu R = 0 \,\end{aligned}\]

we get that

\[\begin{aligned} \alpha (\alpha-1) + \alpha = \mu \,\end{aligned}\]

which after simplifying gives

\[\begin{aligned} \alpha^2 = \mu . \,\end{aligned}\]

Here, the sign of \(\mu\) will affect the form of the solution, so we have three cases to consider. They are

case 1: \(\mu = - \lambda^2 < 0\)

case 2: \(\mu = 0\)

case 3: \(\mu = \lambda^2 > 0\)

Further calculations show that case 2 and case 3 only give trivial solutions. If you are not sure, you should try verifying that yourself. For completeness of the solution, I will also include the computation in the appendix of this solution.

Now, case 1: says that

\[\begin{aligned} \alpha^2 = \mu = - \lambda^2 . \,\end{aligned}\]

This gives

\[\begin{aligned} \alpha = \pm \lambda i .\end{aligned}\]

Recall that for the Euler’s equation, if \(\alpha\) is in the form of \(\alpha = a \pm bi\), the solution of the Euler’s equation can be written as

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_1 r^a \cos(b \ln(r )) + C_2 r^a \sin(b \ln(r )) \,\end{aligned}\]

for some arbitrary constants \(C_1\) and \(C_2\). For us, we have \(a = 0\) and \(b = \lambda\), so our solution for \(R\) is

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_1 \cos(\lambda \ln(r )) + C_2 \sin(\lambda \ln(r )) . \,\end{aligned}\]

Next, we need to match the boundary conditions \(R(1) = 0 \;\; \text{and} \;\; R(2) = 0 . \,\)

\[\begin{aligned} R(1) = 0 \Rightarrow 0 = C_1 \cos(\lambda \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0}) + C_2 \sin(\lambda \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0}) = C_1 \underbrace{\cos(0)}_{=1} + C_2 \underbrace{\sin(0)}_{= 0} = C_1 .\end{aligned}\]

Hence, \(C_1 = 0\) and

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_2 \sin(\lambda \ln(r )) . \,\end{aligned}\]

Now,

\[\begin{aligned} R(2) = 0 \Rightarrow C_2 \sin(\lambda \ln(2)) = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

If \(C_2 = 0\), we will have the trivial solution. To get non-trivial solutions, we need

\[\begin{aligned} \sin(\lambda \ln(2)) = 0 \Rightarrow \lambda \ln(2) = n \pi \Rightarrow \lambda = \frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} .\end{aligned}\]

In other words, we have an infinite numbers of eigenvalues \(\lambda_n\) give by

\[\begin{aligned} \lambda_n = \frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \;\; \text{for} \;\; n = {\color{red}1} ,2,3, \cdots\end{aligned}\]

with the corresponding eigenfunctions

\[\begin{aligned} R_n(r) = C_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) . \,\end{aligned}\]

Now, we will go back to solve the \(\theta\) equation. Recall that we have \(\mu = - \lambda^2\) so the \(\theta\) equation \(- \Theta'' = \mu \Theta\) becomes

\[\begin{aligned} - \Theta'' &= - \lambda^2 \Theta\\ \Theta'' &= \lambda^2 \Theta \end{aligned}\]

which gives solutions of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \Theta = A \cosh(\lambda \theta) + B \sinh(\lambda \theta) \,\end{aligned}\]

for some arbitrary constants \(A\) and \(B\). Since we found that an infinite number of \(\lambda_n = \frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)}\), we have an infinite number of \(\Theta_n\) given by

\[\begin{aligned} \Theta_n = A_n \cosh(\lambda_n \theta) + B_n \sinh(\lambda_n \theta) . \,\end{aligned}\]

Putting everything together, we can express \(u\) as

\[\begin{aligned} u(r,t) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty C_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) \left(A_n \cosh(\lambda_n \theta) + B_n \sinh(\lambda_n \theta) \right) .\end{aligned}\]

We can absorb the arbitrary constant \(C_n\) into \(A_n\) and \(B_n\) to get

\[\begin{aligned} u(r,t) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) \left(A_n \cosh(\lambda_n \theta) + B_n \sinh(\lambda_n \theta) \right) .\end{aligned}\]

Finally, we will use the other two boundary conditions \(u(r,0) = 0\) and \(u(r,\frac{\pi}{2}) = f(r)\) to find \(A_n\) and \(B_n\).

\[\begin{aligned} &u(r,0) = 0 \,\\ &\sum_{n=1}^\infty \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) (A_n \underbrace{\cosh(0)}_{=1} + B_n \underbrace{\sinh(0)}_{=0} ) = 0 \\ &\sum_{n=1}^\infty A_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) = 0 .\\ &A_n = 0 \;\; \text{for each} \;\; n = 1,2,3,\cdots\end{aligned}\]

Hence

\[\begin{aligned} u(r,t) &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin(\lambda_n \ln(r)) \sinh(\lambda_n \theta)\\ &= \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \theta\right)\end{aligned}\]

Finally, to find \(B_n\), we use the last boundary condition

\[\begin{aligned} u\left(r,\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r ) \right).\end{aligned}\]

This boundary condition gives us that

\[\begin{aligned} u\left(r,\frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty B_n \sin\left(\frac{n \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r ) \right) .\end{aligned}\]

If we expand out the summation, we see that

\[\begin{aligned} &B_1 \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_1 \frac{\pi}{2}\right) + {\color{blue} B_2 \sin\left(\frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_2 \frac{\pi}{2}\right) }\\&+ B_3 \sin\left(\frac{3 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r)\right) \sinh\left(\lambda_3 \frac{\pi}{2}\right) + \cdots = {\color{blue} \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r ) \right) }\end{aligned}\]

Here, we see that \(n =2\) is the only term on the left hand side that matches with the right hand side. Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} B_n \sinh\left(\lambda_n \frac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0 \;\; \text{if} \;\; n \not = 2\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} B_2 \sinh \left( \lambda_2 \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = 1\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \Rightarrow B_2 = \frac{1}{\sinh(\lambda_2 \frac{\pi}{2})} = \frac{1}{\sinh(\frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \frac{\pi}{2})} .\end{aligned}\]

In other words, the solution is

\[\begin{aligned} u(r,\theta) = \frac{1}{\sinh \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \frac{\pi}{2} \right) } \sin \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \ln(r) \right) \sinh \left( \frac{2 \pi}{\ln(2)} \theta \right) .\end{aligned}\]

Appendix:

We will address two final questions in this appendix.

Question 1: Refer to the solution above, why doesn’t \(\mu = 0\) lead to non-trivial solutions for the Euler’s equation?

Answer to question 1: Suppose \(\mu = 0\), then

\[\begin{aligned} \alpha^2 = \mu \Rightarrow \alpha = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

The solution to the Euler’s equation is

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_1 \ln(r ) + C_2 \,\end{aligned}\]

for some arbitrary constants \(C_1\) and \(C_2\). The boundary condition \(R(1) = 0\) implies

\[\begin{aligned} R(1) = C_1 \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0} + C_2 = 0 \Rightarrow C_2 = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

So

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_1 \ln(r ) . \,\end{aligned}\]

The boundary condition \(R(2) = 0\) implies

\[\begin{aligned} R(2) = C_1 \ln(2) = 0 \Rightarrow C_1 = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

Hence, we only get the trivial solution.

Question 2: Refer to the solution above, why doesn’t \(\mu = \lambda^2 > 0\) lead to non-trivial solutions for the Euler’s equation?

Answer to question 2: Suppose \(\mu = \lambda^2 > 0\), then

\[\begin{aligned} \alpha^2 = \mu \Rightarrow \alpha = \pm \lambda .\end{aligned}\]

The solution to the Euler’s equation is

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_1 r^\lambda + C_2 r^{- \lambda} \,\end{aligned}\]

for some arbitrary constants \(C_1\) and \(C_2\). The boundary condition \(R(1) = 0\) implies

\[\begin{aligned} R(1) = C_1 + C_2 = 0 \Rightarrow C_1 = - C_2 .\end{aligned}\]

So

\[\begin{aligned} R(r ) = C_1 r^\lambda - C_1 r^{-\lambda} . \,\end{aligned}\]

The boundary condition \(R(2) = 0\) implies

\[\begin{aligned} R(2) = C_1 2^\lambda - C_1 2^{-\lambda} = 0 . \,\end{aligned}\]

If \(C_1 = 0\), we get a trivial solution, so suppose \(C_1 \not = 0\), then we must have

\[\begin{aligned} 2^{\lambda} = 2^{-\lambda} \Rightarrow 2^{2 \lambda} = 1 \Rightarrow \lambda = 0 .\end{aligned}\]

However, this contradicts with our original assumption that \(\lambda^2 > 0\).

:<math> R(1) = C_1 \underbrace{\ln(1)}_{= 0} + C_2 = 0 \Rightarrow C_2 = 0 . </math>
So 
:<math> R(r ) = C_1 \ln(r ) . \, </math>
The boundary condition <math> R(2) = 0 </math> implies
:<math> R(2) = C_1 \ln(2) = 0 \Rightarrow C_1 = 0 . </math>
Hence, we only get the trivial solution.


''Question 2: Refer to the solution above, why doesn't <math> \mu = \lambda^2 > 0 </math> lead to non-trivial solutions for the Euler's equation?''

''Answer to question 2:'' Suppose <math> \mu = \lambda^2 > 0 </math>, then
:<math> \alpha^2 = \mu \Rightarrow \alpha = \pm \lambda . </math>
The solution to the Euler's equation is
:<math> R(r ) = C_1 r^\lambda + C_2 r^{- \lambda}  \, </math>
for some arbitrary constants <math> C_1 </math> and <math> C_2 </math>.
The boundary condition <math> R(1) = 0 </math> implies
:<math> R(1) = C_1 + C_2 = 0 \Rightarrow C_1 = - C_2 . </math>
So 
:<math> R(r ) = C_1 r^\lambda - C_1 r^{-\lambda} . \, </math>
The boundary condition <math> R(2) = 0 </math> implies
:<math> R(2) = C_1 2^\lambda - C_1 2^{-\lambda} = 0 . \, </math>
If <math> C_1 = 0 </math>, we get a trivial solution, so suppose <math> C_1 \not = 0 </math>, then we must have
:<math> 2^{\lambda} = 2^{-\lambda} \Rightarrow 2^{2 \lambda} = 1 \Rightarrow \lambda = 0 . </math>
However, this contradicts with our original assumption that <math> \lambda^2 > 0 </math>.

Consider the following problem involving Laplace’s equation in an annular region:

\(u_{rr} + \frac1{r} u_r + \frac1{r^2}u_{\theta \theta} = 0, \quad 1 < r < 2, \quad 0 < \theta < \pi/2.\)

\(u(1,\theta) = 0, \quad u(2,\theta) = 0, \quad u(r,0) = 0, \quad u(r,\pi/2) = f(r).\)

Use the method of separation of variables to solve the problem when \(f(r) = \sin\left(\frac{2\pi}{\ln(2)}\ln(r)\right).\)
